ANTON BERNSHTEYN
Abstract. Gao, Jackson, and Seward [7] proved that every countably innite group  admits
a nonempty free subshift X  {0, 1}. Furthermore, a theorem of Seward and Tucker-Drob [13]
implies that every countably innite group  admits a free subshift X  {0, 1} that supports an
invariant probability measure. Aubrun, Barbieri, and Thomasse [3] used the Lovasz Local Lemma
to give a short alternative proof of the GaoJacksonSeward theorem. Recently, Elek [6] followed
another approach involving the Lovasz Local Lemma to obtain a dierent proof of the existence
of free subshifts with invariant probability measures for nitely generated soc groups. Using the
measurable version of the Lovasz Local Lemma for shift actions established by the author in [4],
we give a short alternative proof of the existence of such subshifts for arbitrary groups. Moreover,
we can nd such subshifts in any nonempty invariant open set.

action of  on the closure of f (X) is free. Thus, the closure of f (X) is a nonempty free subshift;
moreover, if the action of  on X admits an invariant probability measure, then so does the ac-
tion of  on f (X). This implies that every countable group admits a free subshift supporting an
invariant probability measure.

In [3], Aubrun, Barbieri, and Thomasse gave a short alternative proof of the GaoJackson
Seward theorem on the existence of nonempty free subshifts. The key ingredient of their proof
is the Lovasz Local Lemma (the LLL for short), an immensely important tool in probabilistic
combinatorics, that is often applied in order to establish the existence of combinatorial objects
(such as colorings) satisfying certain constraints. In a very recent paper [6], Elek used an approach
based on nonrepetitive graph colorings and inspired by the ideas of [1] to obtain a dierent proof of
the existence of free subshifts with invariant probability measures in the case of nitely generated
soc groups. Eleks argument also relies heavily on the LLL. The aim of this note is to use the
measurable version of the LLL for shift actions, established by the author in [4], to amplify the
AuburnBarbieriThomasse construction and get a very short alternative proof of the existence
of free subshifts with invariant measures for arbitrary countable groups. Moreover, we show that
such subshifts can be made disjoint from any given proper subshift:
